202207161423|Philosophies

 202307132311|🚪 Stranger Knocks {"cmd":"PIN2","node":"202307132311","music":""}
Stranger Knocks
Protocol
In your philosophy, what should happen when someone knocks on your door asking for help?
🎪 Quest Society
In a quest society, there is a system to handle requests. So you could direct the person seeking up to a quest center or be the person who registers the quest for them.
💬 Discussions

202207161423|Philosophies

 202307130904|🎓 Discussion Roles {"cmd":"PIN2","node":"202307130904","music":""}
Discussion Roles
Definitions
This node lists topics related to roles of discussion participants and terms of related behavior.
Q: What is a Patronizing speech pattern?
A: A patronizing speech pattern is a pattern that attempts to establish an atmosphere of friendliness to mask deception or wrongdoing. It is a form of emotional or social bribery to distract the victim from the injustice that the user had caused.

Example: (Non-neutral response, deflecting blame)

Ann says something mean to Bob. Bob complains and Ann says:
a) "It's just a joke, we are friends, it is okay for friends to joke around, right?"
b) "Relax, my dear."
The following shows other types of responses for comparison.

Neutral response, non-patronizing and non-apologetic:

a) "I meant it as a joke."
b) "I call for a timeout."

Neutral response, non-patronizing, apologetic, but without admitting guilt:

a) "I'm sorry, I meant it as a joke."
b) "I'm sorry. I call for a timeout."

Non-neutral response, deflecting blame, non-patronizing, appear to apologize, without admitting guilt, condescending

a) "I'm sorry, I meant it as a joke. I shall be extra careful when talking to you."
b) "I'm sorry, I call for a timeout. Let me know when you are ready."
Q: What is the point of explaining what a patronizing response is?
A: The explanation is for awareness. People often adopt a speech pattern by familiarity or halo effect (they mimic the speech patterns they heard without considering its role in a given context where they use it).
A person who is never shown what different speech patterns mean would simply use them out of habit. Awareness and knowing the alternatives are among the first steps of escaping such patterns.
In general, in a constructive discussion, there is no intention to disqualify to prevent someone who uses patronizing patterns from participating. If every participants are aware of such patterns, they would already have no effect on the discussion. But when there is evidence that someone is not aware of what they are doing, then it is part of constructive discussion philosophy to increase awareness.
💬 Discussions

🔍 Google Search Console
StarTree: Site search at Google can now see site:https://panarcana.blogspot.com/ !
Sasha: Okay. Then what's next? StarTree: But that only returns one hit. Doing the same for Wikipedia returns 10 billion hits! Sasha: Are there errors on Search Console? StarTree: The https domain at Search Console has a site map, but the non https domain does not. The site map is now added! StarTree: Now indexing is pending...! Sasha: Okay. Should we try playing a new game or continue with 221B? Zoey: XD Sasha: It is Sunday. Evelyn: It is still early, so I think we should do more quests first. Sasha: But if it is early we can start longer games. LRRH: Or longer quest.
🏛️ Loophole
Black: A loophole in law is a situation where a bad behavior is legal. What do you call a situation where a good behavior is illegal?
Ledia: Draconian? Draconic? LRRH: @ChatGPT: If a loophole describes a situation where the law allows something bad to happen, what do you call the situation where the law disallows something good to happen? ChatGPT: The situation you are describing, where the law disallows something good to happen, is often referred to as a "restriction," "barrier," or "prohibition." It represents a scenario where a law or regulation limits or prevents a desirable outcome or action. This can occur when a law is overly strict or fails to account for certain beneficial possibilities or circumstances. In such cases, individuals or groups may advocate for legal reform or the removal of the restrictive provisions to enable the desired positive outcome. Black: I think I will pick the term Barrier LRRH: Loopholes were original arrow slits, the picture of the sieve isn't fitting. Black: But by now the term more closely resembles the holes of a sieve, since arrowslits are GOOD for a fortifications. Tanya: Are we sure that term was not borrowed because arrowslits were also weak points of a castle wall? Sasha: What do you call it when a neutral behavior is made illegal? Black: I think I will call that a restriction. Fina: Or a violation. Black: I think violation is too board and it covers both ways.
✏️ What is good writing?
⭐Helen: What is good writing? what kind of writing do you like to read?
Tanya: I prefer short and direct writing although I write longer than I need. Evelyn: I am okay with longer writing if it helps be understand the situation. Zoey: I like funny dialogues. Ledia: I like the suspense that comes with a DM. But not for every single move because if we have to roll for everything it would really slow down the game. Story. Sasha: So now are we ready to play / practice writing? StarTree: The Guild is -3 for catching up to the monthly pace! Sasha: The game itself would be +1 for @Vacation. StarTree: Sasha assigned each 221B game run to a different chapter: @Detective, then @Puzzle! Sasha: I'm pretty sure that that is fine. Tanya: Function as designed. LRRH: If you want the game would qualify for @Wish also. Sasha: I would take that.
🎲 Dice Roller

Tanya: @StarTree. StarTree: Should it be its own node or part of the side bar? Tanya: Please first make it as a node. StarTree: Roger! StarTree: Adding RND_CoinFlip and RND_Reset. StarTree: In our games, when we "roll dice" we are doing a coin toss where the result can only be ➕ or ➖. Is that what we need? Tanya: Please start with that first. StarTree: 202307161350|Done! StarTree: The guild is now at -1! Sasha: The game is on!

{"type":"chat","id":"202307161157","parentid":"202207112218","parentname":"Search Visibility","icon":"🔍","title":"Guild Quests","prev":"202307041800","author":"StarTree","location":"Home Channel"}

202207161423|Philosophies

 202307161217|🏛️ Loophole {"cmd":"PIN2","node":"202307161217","music":""}
Loophole
Definition
A loophole in the law is a false positive where the law incorrectly allow a morally wrong behavior to be legal.
Loopholes are situations in the law where bad behavior is made or left being legal. Barriers are situations in the law where good behavior is made illegal. When the law and moral are completely aligned, there should be no loophole and no barrier in the law.
💬 Discussions
{"id":"202307161217","parentid":"202207161423","parentname":"Philosophies","icon":"🏛️","title":"Loophole","subtitle":"Definition","img":"https://cdn.pixabay.com/photo/2016/02/03/19/04/sieve-1177720_1280.jpg","music":"","author":"Black","description":"","card-text":""}

202207131009|Board Games

 202307161350|🎲 Dice Roller {"cmd":"PIN2","node":"202307161350","music":""}
Dice Roller
Gadget
💰 Coin Flip
{"cmd":"url","url":"https://g.co/kgs/eU4mM6","desc":"🎲 Google Dice"} 💬 Discussions
{"id":"202307161350","parentid":"202207131009","parentname":"Board Games","icon":"🎲","title":"Dice Roller","subtitle":"Gadget","img":"https://cdn.pixabay.com/photo/2014/12/14/18/33/cube-568105_1280.jpg","music":"","author":"StarTree","description":"","card-text":""}
🔔
This is Magic Bakery Plays 221B Baker Street Case 6! The game content is probably rated teens to adult. ⚠️ Sasha: We will enter drumroll after revealing 5 clues. If you want to get a WIN credit you must join before the drumroll section.
🚨 Case 6: The Murdered Banker
Sasha: The vice president and controller of a bank is found murdered in his bank office. Magic Detectives are called to find the killer, the weapon, and the motive.
Sasha: I think it is easier to break down the initial description into sections. last time I broke it down to persons and the scene. This time it seems the timeline is the most relevant. But first are the scene and persons.
⭐ Crime Scene
Evelyn: The victim was found slumped over his desk atop a pile of scattered papers. He had been hit on the right side of the head with a blunt object.
Tanya: The lock on the victim's file cabinet was broken. It appeated that some papers had been removed from the files.
Black: It looks like we are looking for someone left-handed.
⭐ Timeline
StarTree: Here is the timeline according to the statements:
9:30 AM: The Secretary left the office to pick up theater tickets at the Playhouse for the victim and his wife. The Secretary said that when she left the office, the victim was alone in his office.
9:30 AM: The victim's calendar shows that from 9:30am to 10:00am, he has a meeting with the vice president of commercial lending section.
9:50 AM: The VP of lending said he did meet with the victim, but when he left at 9:50am, the victim was in good health.
9:50 AM: The Treasurer, whose office is next to the victim, said he heard a noise from the victim's office as if he dropped a briefcase.
10:00 AM: Secretary returns and finds the body.
⭐ Persons
Victim: Vice President and Controller of the bank. Married.
Secretary: Found the victim's body when she returned from the playhouse.
VP of Lending: Had a meeting with the victim. Disagreed strongly with the victim on many policies.
Treasurer: Heard noise from his own office next to the victim's.
Black: A theory: The VP of lending killed the victim because he went against the bank policy and gave some bad loans. So he wanted to steal evidence from the victim's cabinet. 44: I agree that the person who opened the cabinet is trying to steal evidence, but the murderer could be a different person. The Treasurer could have heard the murder, then took the opportunity to steal from the cabinet when the victim is already dead. Tanya: But what is the murder weapon? The only object being described is the sound of a briefcase. Ledia: I don't think you can kill someone with a briefcase. Briefcases in 1900's were probably made of leather. Evelyn: I think the murderer is not the VP of lending because if he had already been disagreeing with the victim many times, what makes him want to kill the victim this time? Black: Maybe he ran out of patience and started acting against policies. Evelyn: Okay. Sasha: First clue. Where? Zoey: Getting a clue from the Bank will probably tell us something very obvious. But for the RP we can't really not get it. Tanya: So far we are doing quite well just following the rational path. Let's start at the Bank.
🔍 [15] Bank
Zoey: Later that day, the victim is scheduled to give a report on the bank's profit.
Tanya: I think this clue quite safely rule out the wife or the secretary as murder suspects, since the motive should be about money. This is a bit of meta-graming since we know that most of the clues in the game matter. Zoey: I didn't get a chance to do something magical. XD Tanya: We need a clue about the treasurer or the lender.
🔍 [75] Newspaper Shop
Black: Black checked the news for financial clues and found that the Treasurer had been having a rather lavish life style for the past two years. It would appear that he had obtained an inheritance or another source of income.
Black: I think this points to the Treasurer being the one who stole evidence of his embezzlement. But as 44 said, he might not be the murderer. Tanya: Akram's Razor: The treasurer is also the murderer. He has the motive, and the opportunity (when the victim is alone, since the secretary is gone and no one else is scheduled to be there after VP of ledning left). VP of lending does not have a motive yet. It would be strange if he killed the victim during his scheduled meeting time. Ledia: Compelling. Sasha: Then, what is the murder weapon? 44: If the Treasurer stole papers from the cabinet, why are the papers scattered on the desk? Tanya: The murder weapon is the paperweight. The murderer removed it from the crime scene.
🔍 [35] Dock
LRRH: Having suspicion that the murderer was the Treasurer, LRRH asked Sirius to backtrace his tracks this morning. His scent ended at the ditch. "Are you telling me that Mr. Treasurer went to the ditch and back?" Little Red asks Sirius.
LRRH: My clue was a syllable clue for the killer. Part 2 of 2: The opposite of Woman. In the original game, the victim's name is Ostermann and the Treasurer's name is Bakman. So this clue is not conclusive. It could be the victim, the victim's wife, or the Treasurer. Tanya: But if our guess and RP is correct, the Treasurer dumped the paperweight into the ditch. Sasha: The game doesn't require us to find the weapon, but for RP we should find it, since without the murder weapon we don't really have evidence to connect the Treasurer to the victim's room during the crime. Ledia: Even if we find the paper that he stole from the cabinet, we don't have evidence for murder. Sasha: Two clues left to find a clue about the weapon. Should we challenge ourselves that if we can't find the weapon, the murderer doesn't get convicted? Ledia: We are not entirely sure that the weapon is a paperweight. It could have been a book. Or a statue. Black: The secretary should know if there was a paperweight.
🔍 [105] Playhouse
Ledia: Ledia asked the Secretary if there was a paperweight, which she confirmed.
Ledia: The clue is a weapon syllable clue. Part 1 of 3: Crime doesn't _____. Ledia: I can't think of any word order than Pay, and I can't think of any weapon other than Paperweight. Sasha: Okay. I think I am okay with finding the paperweight in the drumroll section, which would be inevitable. So we will keep playing and see who gets the other two clues for the weapon.
🔍 [95] Pawnbroker
Casey: Casey scans the ditch with a metal detector and finds the paperweight in the ditch, and sends it back to the lab.
Ivy: At the lab, Ivy lifted a fingerprint from the paperweight and asks the team to send in some fingerprints to match with.
Casey: This was a killer syllable clue. Part 1 of 2 is the opposite of front. That matches the VP of Lending and the Treasurer. So the killer is definitely the Treasurer. Zoey: I think as long as you find the paperweight we have magical evidence that the Treasurer did it. Sasha: Anymore changes? Drumroll? Tanya: We did not get any motive clue. Black: We did get a motive clue, just not a syllable motive clue. Zoey: I'm fine with having a little tension during drumroll. XD Sasha: Okay then, Drumroll!
🥁 [5] Apothecary
Sasha: This is a motive syllable clue. Part 3 of 4: The alphabet letter after K.
🥁 [25] Carriage Depot
Sasha: This is a motive syllable clue. Part 4 of 4: The past tense of mean.
🥁 [45] Hotel
Sasha: This clue says that the Victim and the Secretary spend the night together at the Hotel sometimes.
Ledia: I think this is evidence that the game does give misleading clues. We should remember this. Tanya: Noted.
🥁 [55] Locksmith
Sasha: This is a motive syllable clue. Part 1 of 4: The alphabet letter after L.
🥁 [65] Museum
Sasha: This is a motive syllable clue. Part 2 of 4: The sound a bee makes.
🥁 [80] Park
Sasha: This is a weapon syllable clue. Part 3 of 3: ___ til the sun shines, Nellie (song title)
🥁 [115] Pub
Sylvia: Both the Secretary and the VP of Lending are left-handed.
Zoey: Hold on. Didn't we say we are looking for a left-handed murderer? Tanya: But we already know from killer syllable clue that the killer is the Treasurer. 44: It would make sense if the Treasurer was trying to frame the VP of Lending.
🥁 [125] Scotland Yard
Evelyn: The victim was hit on the head from behind.
Zoey: There. XD
🥁 [135] Tobacconist
Sasha: This is a weapon syllable clue. Part 2 of 3: The sound made by a contented cat.
🛎️ SOLUTION
Sasha: After further investigation and questioning the detectives were able to reveal the full story. Sasha: For the past two years, the Treasurer had been embezzling money from the bank. The victim confronted the Treasurer about it, and said he would reveal the truth at the meeting later that day if the Treasurer doesn't do that himself. WIth that, the Treasurer decided to kill the victim, striking him from behind with the paperweight. He then stole the evidence from the cabinet, burnt the documents, and discarded the ash and the paperweight into the ditch.
Ledia: If he burnt the documents, how did we get the evidence that he committed embezzlement? Sasha: Do we care? We got him for murder. Evelyn: I think there could be more than one copy of those documents. Zoey: In the Briefcase under his desk. XD Ledia: I'd take that answer. Sasha: Congratulations to all for winning! Please return for the next case!
Sasha thanks the players!
⚔️ EXTRA
Sasha: As you may know, we have a lot more games than 221B Baker Street. 221B Baker Street has 200 cases. If we play just that it would take us at least two years to finish. Why don't we also try some other games? Or should I ask, who wants to try another game while we continue to play 221B Baker Street?
Tanya: That highly depends on what other games you want to try. Sasha: Among the latest games we got are Pathfinder, Diplomacy, Epic Seven, and Last Night on Earth. Evelyn: Are they all cooperative games? Sasha: Diplomacy is not. Black: Last Night On Earth is not good for playing online. It needs a board and many movements and dice rolling. Sasha: I think we can abstract or simplifying it for an RP version. We play as ourselves like a TTRPG. We don't need to use the board or roll for movement on the board. We can take all of those away. Sasha: We just care about the story and adventures we have together, in a zombie infested place. Black: But if you do that don't you need to practically design a new game? Sasha: Not really. We are not designing the quest or the items in the game. We just make it simpler. Ledia: That's pretty compelling. But. I think it will take too long compared to 221B. Sasha: We don't have to finish in one session. Zoey: We didn't finish the first chapter of Mice and Mystics. XD Evelyn: If we are going to start a new game, I would rather finish Mice and Mystics, because I want to know how the story ends. Ledia: I think by now we know everything in the item deck. We are not familiar with all the skills, but I suppose those details are what we need to abstract away. Ledia: If you just want to know how it ends you could just read the story book. Evelyn: If I do that there is no surprise when we continue. 😅 Sasha: How about we try to continue with a simplfied version of Mice and Mystics? I want to confirm that we can just play any game without necessarily following the game's rules, because we have our Magic Bakery rules. Evelyn: I am okay with that. Ledia: I am not in that game but I am curious how that works. Zoey: If that works we can burn through Sasha's collection. XD Sasha: Yes, it is worth trying isn't it. Sasha: @Cardinal, is that doable? Cardinal: Yes it is doable. I will take the liberty to abstract the rules and dispense the story elements. Sasha: Let's call for a game and see how it goes.

🔔
This is Magic Bakery plays Mice & Mystics, chapter 1 tile 4: The Kitchen. Sasha: This session follows Magic Bakery game rules instead of the official rules.
📯 The Kitchen
Cardinal: The Hero mice answer the cries of Kitchen staff Maggie and rushed to a kitchen where Maggie is frantically defending the kitchen from roaches with her broom.
Sasha: Since this is an unplanned session, let's see who are here to play. Evelyn: I am playing Tilda, a cleric mouse. Casey: I was the blacksmith mouse. Sasha: That is Nez. Zoey: I want to play. XD Sasha: Do you want to play Collin? Zoey: I will take anything. XD Sasha: Then you are Prince Collin. Sasha: @P4? P4: P4 wants to play with Evelyn. Sasha: P4 can be Tilda when she attacks. P4: 💟 Sylvia: May I play Filch the Rogue? Sasha: Perfect. Cardinal please go.
Cardinal: The mice heroes see roaches on the floor and on the kitchen counter, as well as a broom coming their way, "MIIIICE!!!" screams Maggie.
Cardinal: Everyone rolls for defense. Collin and Filch with advantage. Zoey: Prince Collin: ➖➕ P4: Tilda: ➖ Sylvia: Filch: ➖➖ Casey: Nez: ➕ Cardinal: Collin and Nez barely deflect the broom, but the group was swept toward the wall away from the table. Cardinal: Heroes, what would you like to achieve in the kitchen? Sasha: The story is that the heroes are supposed to clear the roaches and get Maggie's attention. Evelyn: Do we actually look like mice? I though we are wearing armor and holding weapons. Cardinal: As the heroes wonder how they appear to Maggie, the roaches on the floor have closed in onto them. One group surrounding Collin and Tilda, the other around Nez and Filch. Zoey: No time to talk. XD Zoey: Prince Collin uses his sword skill against the roaches. Evelyn: I forgot what skills Tilda has. 😖 Sasha: I think at this point we don't really care. Just do what you think would make sense. Evelyn: It all happened so quickly, Tilda casts Protect for the whole group. Cardinal: Please describe the action for Nez and Filch also, They will be resolved at once. Casey: The sweep got Nez's blood pumping and he does his all around swing with his long hammer. Sylvia: At the first sign that Nez is going to make that move, Filch uses the momentum of Nez's swing to leap onto the table. Cardinal: Everyone rolls two dice please. Zoey: Collin: ➕➖ Evelyn: Tilda: ➕➕ Casey: Nez: ➕➕ Sylvia: Filch: ➕➕ Cardinal: Filch's acrobatic move surprised Nez and caused him to lose balance, where his hammer makes a second swing at the roaches. As he curses Filch while regaining balance, he realized that the roaches around him are all defeated. Cardinal: On the other hand, Prince Collin defeats one roach, while Tilda's protect connected just in time to block the remaining two attacking roaches on the floor. Cardinal: ➕➖➖➕ Cardinal: Maggie takes a swing at the three mice on the floor. Roll two dice for defense. Zoey: Collin: ➕➖ Evelyn: Tilda: ➕➖ Casey: Nez: ➖➕ Cardinal: The three mice are pushed against the wall. Evelyn's protect is just barely holding.
⚔️ Table and Floor
Cardinal: On the table, Filch sees two roaches eating the cheese. On the floor, Maggie trying to finish off the Collin, Tilda, and Nez along with two roaches. Cardinal: Heroes, make your choices.
Sylvia: Filch backstabs the two roaches, and hides under the table if succeed. Zoey: Collin will take on one roach and leave the other for Nez. Casey: Nez will carefully finish the remaining roach. Evelyn: Tilda casts divine seal, which by itself has a calming effect, and it is something that Maggie had seen Tilda do before. Tilda is trying to let Maggie know that they were turned into mice. Cardinal: Everyone rolls two dice please. Zoey: Collin: ➖➕ Casey: Nez: ➖➖ Sylvia: Filch: ➕➕ Evelyn: Tilda: ➖➕ Cardinal: Filch easily clears the roaches on the table top, but noticed that Nez missing his swing... Sylvia: I use blink to backstab that roach also. Cardinal: ➖➖➕➖ Sylvia is recognized for the skills Backstab and Blink. Evelyn is recognized for the skill Divine Seal.
⚔️ Bewildered
Cardinal: Tilda's divine seal let Maggie see that the mice were clearing the roaches. Maggie holds the broom close to her and looks at the group in bewilderment. Tilda could sense that Maggie is under a spell that prevents her from seeing the hero mice the same way as the heroes see themselves.
Cardinal: Heroes, now you may choose to go back down the tunnel to escape the castle, or stay and get item or spell. If you choose to stay, there is a chance of another encounter. Evelyn: I think we should go back down and this is a good time to stop. Zoey: I agree with going back down but I want to do another tile. XD Casey: I don't mind going one more tile. Sylvia: I am okay with going another tile. Evelyn: Okay, let's go down.
Tanya: Maggie is under a curse, said Maginos the Mystics from under the tunnel. Let's get out of the castle first. With that, the group returned to the tunnel. Sasha: Oops. I forgot that there were actually five mice on scene. Zoey: XD
⚔️ Tunnel Spider
Cardinal: As the heroes descend to the kitchen tunnel, they notice a giant spider coming their way.
Sylvia: I hide and prepare for backstab. Evelyn: Do we still have to fight everything? This is just a spider. 😅 Zoey: You could try to cast sleep while I block it. Casey: I go into position to attack if sleep fails. Cardinal: Everyone rolls two dice please. Sylvia: Filch: ➕➖ Evelyn: Tilda: ➕➖ Zoey: Collin: ➖➕ Casey: Nez: ➕➖ Cardinal: Spider: ➖➕➕➕ Cardinal: As Tilda casts Sleep, the Spider sprays poison at the group. Everyone but Filch receives one poison damage. In the chaos, Collin and Nez swung at the Spider, but it fended off their attacks. Filch is now in position to strike. Tilda sees that her Sleep spell has no effect on the Spider. Cardinal: Nez, Collin, and Tilda are at 2 HP. Filch is at 3 HP. Heroes please choose your next move. Evelyn: I cast remove poison. Zoey: Collin will defensively attack for Nez and Filch to make the kill. Casey: Nez will swing carefully for a big hit. Sylvia: Filch will make a hit as soon as the spider is focused on attacking Collin or Nez. Cardinal: Everyone rolls two dice please. Evelyn: Tilda: ➖➕ Zoey: Collin: ➖➕ Casey: Nez: ➖➖ Sylvia: Filch: ➖➕ Cardinal: Spider: ➕➖➕➖ Cardinal: The heroes are having a hard time finding an opening. While Tilda removes the poison on the group, the spider's long legs struck Nez. Nez is now down to 1 HP. The Spinder is still in full health. Casey: I place a trap and fall back. Evelyn: I heal Nez. Zoey: I lure the Spider toward the trap. Sylvia: Still waiting for the opportunity for a killing blow. Cardinal: Everyone rolls two dice please. Casey: Nez: ➖➖ Evelyn: Tilda: ➕➖ Zoey: Collin: ➕➖ Sylvia: Filch: ➖➕ Cardinal: Spider: ➕➖➕➖ Cardinal: The Spider hit Nez again preventing him form laying down a trap. Evelyn's healing is barely keeping Nez from a KO. Cardinal: As the heroes struggle with the Spider, they hear the sound of more creatures approaching from the tunnels. Zoey: Let's back toward the exit. Maybe we can just leave the spider alone, or have it fight the ones coming through the tunnel. Casey: I back off behind Collin. Evelyn: I cast group heal. Sylvia: I will take an opportunity to strike then go back to the front of the Spider for the escape. Cardinal: Everyone rolls two dice please. Evelyn: Tilda: ➕➕ Zoey: Collin: ➖➖ Sylvia: Filch: ➖➖ Casey: Nez: ➕➖ Cardinal: Spider: ➖➖➕➕ Cardinal: The Spider's defense is too high. The heroes could not land any solid hit. Filch takes a wound trying to make a hit as the Spider turned around and spit sticky webs. It seems that the Spider is more interested in trapping the incoming creatures than to pursue the hero mice. Evelyn is recognized for the skill Remove Poison.
Cardinal: The hero mice continues to the next section of the tunnel, hoping for better luck. Cardinal: Hero Status: Collin and Tilda: 3/3 HP, Nex 2/4 HP, Filch 2/3 HP.
Sasha: Okay, I think that's all we have time for today. Is this doable? Too hard? Too easy? Evelyn: I think this pace is fine if we only do one tile. Zoey: I don't know what Collin can do. XD Casey: Do we basically have all skills? Cardinal: You have skills that make sense at this point of the story. Ledia: I think you can still describe conditions to some degree. Tanya: I think Evelyn could try to use charm on the spider. You could try to do that on creatures that can't fall asleep. Evelyn: I'll try. Sasha: There will be plenty of opportunities to upgrade the gameplay, so please let us know your ideas. See you next game!
Sasha thanks the players.

202207161423|Philosophy

 202307170949|🛎️ Agent Governance {"cmd":"PIN2","node":"202307170949","music":""}
Agent Governance
Philosophy
The agent model of governance sets the government as a collection of agents that do what the people and individuals are allowed to do. Public decisions and workflows are broken down into accessible subprocesses so that the citizens can perform them by themselves without creating authority figures.
Q: What is the opposite of an agent model of government? An agent as opposed to what?
A: As opposed to a top-down authoritarian style of governance where the government is the principal. An authoritarian style of governance has a monopoly on government processes and treats the people as agents to complete the government's goals.
Q: Does this mean anyone can run the license plates and everyone knows where everyone lives?
A: Yes if that is the law of the zone. A zone could have a law where that information is not collected. In a fully open zone, you could run license plates, and know where everyone lives just as they also may know where you live.
Q: What is the advantage of making everything DIY?
A: The main reason that the governance is fundamentally DIY is that it doesn't violate autonomy and it doesn't reward "deadweight" tasks.

Deadweight or inefficiency happens when a person who is motivated or efficient at a task is kept from doing it, while a person not as motivated or efficient is assigned to do the task instead.

In an agent model, the person who needs a public task completed may select any competent and available agent to perform the task. This means that when there are multiple choices, the requester may choose the more efficient one.
Q: Why would there be multiple choices of agents? Or how do you know if there will be more or fewer choices in this model?
A: In general monopoly reduces choices. Therefore when the government does not create an artificial monopoly (by contracting just one out of two companies to perform city service), the people can figure out which service provider they want (some selecting company A, some selecting company B). With that, there is no need for a city council to analyze and make a broad-stroke predictive decision. The choices could be compared and reviewed by the people as they choose the provider they want.
Q: Say the city only has space for one school. If you want to let people choose, don't you need two schools? how does that work?
A: In principle, the agent model will let the people choose as much as they can. If there can only be one school then the school could be treated as a public facility asset where different teachers or teaching associations borrow individual classrooms or time slots. The association gets more room or time slots depending on the number of students that choose them instead of the alternatives.
Q: How is the agent model different from privatization?
A: The gist of the issue is not whether a service provider is public or private, but whether the individuals needing the service have choices so that can choose the more efficient one, and whether the more efficient one gets more resources to expand its good practices to serve more.

The agent model opens the workflow so that the person who needs a public service done is allowed to complete it themselves. When a person cannot perform the task themself, the person may choose to spend the corresponding resources on any agent they appoint.

"Privatization" may include operation modes where the person in need is not allowed to perform the task themself, but *must* select a company to do it for them, or exist in a way that the service become unaffordable. When those modes are not happening, privatization can be considered an implementation of the agent model. The agent model can be implemented as a public entity. A citizen going through an open public workflow is just a participating citizen of the public process. It is like performing self-checkout at the supermarket, the customer doesn't become an employee of the supermarket nor a self-employed person in the eye of the law just because they performed a self-checkout.

A government agency, even if it is a single agency, can practice or expand on the agent model letting people choose among different implementations or management, then assign resources according to the people's preferences.

For example, if a city council normally has five members, a step toward full agent model governance is to simply let the voters pick one candidate, and the council is composed of the top five candidates (Instead of dividing the city into districts and letting each district decide one member by majority rule. Such a method is a type of divide-and-conquer tactic that can be exploited to violate autonomy. In an agent model, a dispersed minority of 49% would still get 49% of consumable decision power, whereas, in a district election system, the 49% would get no decision power because they can lose to the majority in every district.)

Further steps closer to an agent model, is to let each voter endorse their representative and distribute decision power according to a representative's number of endorsements. When that happens, the representatives are no longer elected, they are selected directly by the people who support them. A person can switch their representative at will and the corresponding decision power goes to the new representative.
💬 Discussions
{"id":"202307170949","parentid":"202207161423","parentname":"Philosophy","icon":"🛎️","title":"Agent Governance","subtitle":"Philosophy","img":"https://cdn.pixabay.com/photo/2018/02/01/14/09/field-3123271_1280.jpg","music":"","author":"Black","description":"","card-text":""}
🔔
This is for GitHub migration topics. Let's talk about the layout.
📐 Column Workspace
Ivy: This is a suggestion from Sasha, that the new website would have columns, where the user could just add columns and display content on each one individually like viewing a few phones at once. Ivy: And when the device is a phone (when the screen width is below a number), there will just be one a single column.
Sasha: I got that idea from Tweet Deck. Tanya: I think sometimes we need wider columns. I think that is one of the reasons for the migration: that we could use the full width of the screen. Ivy: @StarTree please start a mockup so we could discuss details. StarTree: Should there be a top or bottom menu bar? Sasha: Eventhough the top bar is mostly useless I think we need it, otherwise the website would just look strange. Ledia: Where do you put the buttons? How do you configure what is displayed in a column? Tanya: And how do you add a column? Black: I would say let's start with the absolute necessary before trying something fancy. Black: I think what is necessary is to retain JQuery nodes so that a panel can display content. Ivy: We know how to do that already. Black: Then? Ivy: But if you start migrating the content, or start using the GitHub location, there will be duplicate content to maintain. Black: I think the HTML content for Archive1 and Archive2 can be exactly the same. What GitHub is missing is the corresponding code for Viewer at the GitHub index.html. Ivy: We are designing the layout for index.html. That is the new thing that we need to decide on. Black: I guess I am saying I would like to see a copy of the current layout so that we can migrate to GitHub, then we can upgrade the layout. Tanya: What is the point of migrating if it is exactly the same? Black: Then we literally can focus on one website as we upgrade it. Ledia: I lean toward just using the GitHub website as a sandbox to visualize new layout. It just feels safer when we know we can mess around with it without worrying that someone needs to post something. Ivy: That's my intention. Black: Understood. Ledia: In our current site, when you click on a link on the sidebar it opens the content in the main area. If you let the user make any number of column, do you mean each column has its own sidebar and main area? Ivy: The concept is that any column could be the sidebar. It is not decided what happens when you click on a link. Ivy: My idea is that when you click on a link, it would open on the closest column that is not a sidebar. Tanya: I am fine with it always create a new column with the content. The user can always close the extra columns. Sasha: I think it would be annoying if you need to close it. Black: How about you can add a lock on a column so that when you click on a link, the content goes to a column that is not locked? Tanya: I am fine with that. Vivi: How would this all work on a phone? Black: I think a sidebar can be locked by default on desktop, but unlocked by default on a phone. Each column can have a button to make itself a sidebar. On a phone, when the sidebar is locked, it loads content to an unlocked column or makes a column above itself. Ledia: Then it is very similar to what we have now. Ivy: @StarTree please make a mockup at GitHub. StarTree: Wee~~!
Wee~~!

202207161423|Philosophies

 202307192022|🏅 License & Certificate {"cmd":"PIN2","node":"202307192022","music":""}
License & Certificate
Philosophy
Does your philosophy uses licenses and certificates? How do they work?
Quest Society
In general when there is a mutual agreement, a person does not need a license to provide help or to practice a profession. It is illegal to lie about one's competence or experience. A person requesting help is allowed to choose only helpers who are certified.
💬 Discussions

🔔
On Nextdoor I have a routine of checking notifications and responding. But when I do I create content that is in Nextdoor but not on the guild. Black: In this thread I want to discuss the proper workflow to archive and reuse. The topic is very similar to Albatross.
🗃️ Nextdoor Group
Black: On Nextdoor I created a group which has a similar function as the Albatross. In the group I post generic explanatory material so that I could link to when responding. It is meant to save myself from writing the same thing repeatedly. Black: Another reason that it is at Nextdoor is that the topic of the discussions originate from Nextdoor, so having a link in the same domain is less suspicious. Black: A third but important reason is that Nextdoor has a policy of keeping topics local in the main feed. Philosophical topics are at risk of being deleted. By posting them in the group then link to it, the main content (the effort) is kept even if the original thread is deleted in the main area.
📯 Workflow and Priority
Black: In the morning, I check notifications and remove those I don't plan to respond to. For those I want to respond to, I either respond directly in the original thread, or create a post in the Group, then respond in the original thread with a link to the group post. Black: There is no routine to move content from the main thread to the group, or from the group back to the guild. Black: That's because there is almost always something to respond to, so after responding I run out of time already.
Tanya: If you don't post in the guild you are not getting XP for the content. Black: Correct. But I run out of time. And I think there is a higher priority to respond than to archive. Tanya: I think you could start with straightly posting in the group and link to them to keep the main thread response short. Tanya: As for archiving, you could either start at the guild, then copy to Nextdoor group and link to thread, or have another routine/monthly quest board quest to archive the content from the group to the guild. Black: I prefer starting at the group then copy back to the guild because when I post at Nextdoor there is spellcheck. Black: And I think the content I create is related to many chapters: Arena, Carrot, Dungeon, Freedom, Happy, Seed, Skill, Whale. So if anyone wants to they can import that content to guild. Tanya: I see. Let's go through the routine today so I can see better.
🔍 Notifications
Black: So right now there are 9 new notifications.
Topic 1: Parking in downtown. Black: This topic is highly related to Choice Democracy so I keep it for responding. Nextdoor automatically deletes notifications so it might be worth saving this link to Guild Log.
Topic 2: Pesticide Spraying notification. Black: This is the topic where I was responding to this week. I have two long posts that I saved on Notepad++ in case the main thread is deleted. That content is not in the group. Black: I didn't start in the group and link because I needed to connect the dots on who in the thread is a "principal" and who is an "agent". If I start in the group, I think I would need to copy and summarize the main thread, which would take longer. Black: But I see the opportunities to start in the group knowing that when I link to it, I could add short explanation in the main thread post.
Black: After removing other topics that I don't plan to respond to, my notifications section has 6 links.
Tanya: Do you know how long a notification would stay? Black: I think maybe one month. Tanya: I think as long as you plan to respond, you should save the link. Black: I do have a section in the group to just archive links to posts in a topic. Zoey: I think I will make a node for obstacle types. That seems to be a new concept to the guild.
Black thanks all for the attention.
{"type":"chat","id":"202307200919","parentid":"202307231022","parentname":"Nextdoor Workflow","icon":"📯","title":"Nextdoor Workflow","prev":"202307062123","author":"Black","location":"Log Fall Dungeon"}

202207161423|Philosophies

 202307202150|🚧 Obstacle Types {"cmd":"PIN2","node":"202307202150","music":""}
Obstacle Types
Analysis
This node is about the types of obstacles to changes. Identifying the obstacles gives a clearer picture on what needs to be done to make changes, or let the changes happen by itself.
Moral Obstacle
Moral obstacle exists when a person cannot tell what is morally right or wrong to do in a given situation.
Judgment Obstacle
Judgment obstacle exists when a person makes a conclusion from wrong logic.
Knowledge Obstacle
Knowledge obstacle exists when lacks information or knowledge to proceed.
Idea Obstacle
Idea obstacle exists when a person runs out of idea to resolve a situation.
💬 Discussions

202207161423|Philosophies

 202307202225|🏎️ Speed Limit {"cmd":"PIN2","node":"202307202225","music":""}
Speed Limit
Law
This node discusses and compares speed limit laws under different philosophies.
Purpose
The purpose of speed limit laws is to define what one may expect in an environment so that people can be informed before they enter.
Common Speed Limit
To not violate autonomy, so that damage is reasonably minimized, a suggested law is "No one shall enter someone's personal space at an unsafe speed. In case of an accidental collision, the faster entity is at fault." Personal space is approximately within a person's arm length. An unsafe speed is approximate a speed difference of 10 mph. The more fragile the entities are the lower the unsafe speed difference.
💬 Discussions

🔔
The law game continues. Natalie: Please be aware that the content may not be appropriate for children, and that we play this game from a philosophical standpoint. The answers are not meant to be representative of all jurisdictions.
[15] Overlapping Convictions
🏛️Natalie: Ms Diamond is charged with illegal possession of narcotics, illegal possesion with intent to sell, and possession of drugs in improperly labeled containers. May she be convicted of all three?
Fina: In reciprocative justice those are three different offenses, so yes, she can be convicted of all three. The corresponding law are written so that they do not overlap. So if there is illegal possession of narcotics, the next offense is intention to sell illegal substances. Tanya: As written, no, this is because at least the first two overlap. If you find two laws that overlap, then you would only be convicted with the one that includes more. In those three, the second and third offenses do not overlap. But since the question asks whether she may be convicted of all three, the answer is no. Natalie: The card's answer is exactly as Tanya say, she could be convicted of the 1st and 3rd, or the 2nd and 3rd, but not all three at once.
🏛️ [19] Intent
Natalie: Under what two circumstances is one said to intend the results of his acts?
Sasha: Reasonable belief that the actor knows what would happen if their action takes place; and reasonable belief of evidence that the actor had prepare to carry out the action, or that the actor actually carried out the action. Natalie: It is close! The card's answer are desire and knowledge. Desire means the actor wants the result to happen, and knowledge is what Sasha said, that the actor knows that his actions would cause the result.
🏛️ [20] Double Tapping
Natalie: Dracula, Mummy, and Werewolf are playing a card game. Mummy found that Dracula had been cheating, and beats Dracula dead. Without knowing that Dracula had died, Werewolf joined in and slashed Dracula's throat. Can Werewolf be charged with murder?
Fina: Yes. In reciprocative laws, murder is about the intention in combination of the action. Even if Dracula does not end up dying, the two would be guilty of murder. In your law that would be called attempted murder, and murder refers to when the victim actually dies. Casey: So, in short, yes. Natalie: The card's answer is NO. The reason is as Fina said, in the terminology that this card uses, what Werewolf committed would be attempted the murder, not murder. Fina: And to that I disagree with the card's law. In reciprocative law, both Mummy and Werewolf would qualify for murder, and Werewolf would qualify for more severe crime because if it is not obvious that Dracula died from Mummy's attack. Mummy could still argue that he didn't intent to kill Dracula. But that defense would not fly for Werewolf. Fina: So in reciprocative law, Mummy might qualify for assault, but Werewolf would qualify for murder, even when Dracula was already dead from Mummy's attacks. Tanya: I think Fina's explanation makes more sense. If you kill P4 now knowing that that is P4's decoy, that should still be murder. Sasha: Exactly. Zoey: And that takes care of the situation when the victim is rescued or resurrected. Just because the victim is saved should not lessen what the crime was.
Natlie thanks all for playing!
{"type":"chat","id":"202307211946","parentid":"202301011739","parentname":"Law Game","icon":"⚖️","title":"Law Game Part 11","prev":"189912300000","author":"Natalie","location":"Paladin Hall"}
🔔
Hey Hey Hey! It is your beloved puzzle master Mikela!
⭐ Mirror Mirror
Mikela: Why do mirrors flip left and right, but not up and down?
Sasha: Wait, this is not a puzzle. This is straight science isn't it? Mikela: It is a puzzle worthy science question! Mikela: That our dear, one and only Sasha logged in guild log for @Puzzle! Sasha: I knew it sounded familiar! Amelia: Because our eyes are side by side Sasha: But it is the same if you look in the mirror with one eye closed. Sasha: So I stumpled across this question and there there is an explanation {"cmd":"url","url":"https://bigthink.com/starts-with-a-bang/mirrors-flip-left-right-up-down/","desc":"[link]"}. But it still don't understand it. Can someone explain it in simpler terms? Zoey: @ChatGPT XD ChatGPT: Mirrors flip left and right, but not up and down because of how they reflect light. When light bounces off our body and hits the mirror, it behaves like a ball bouncing off a wall, bouncing back in the opposite direction. So, when light from our right side hits the mirror, it reflects to the left, and light from our left side reflects to the right, creating the appearance of left-right reversal in the reflection. Ivy: It makes total sense if you start from your eye, draw a straight line to the mirror, and reflect it to see where that line would reach Sasha: I feel dumb. ChatGPT and Ivy's answers are more clear than the front and back explanation. Amelia: The mirror doesn't flip left and right. What is on the right is still on the right. Black: What is on the right is still on the right. Sasha: That's true. Tanya: But I understand the front and back answer. Imagine you pass a 3D mask to a waterfall, and as it passes through the waterfall, you flip the mask inside out. Then on the other side of the waterfall, the mask has left and right flipped but not up and down. 44: I also like the front and back explanation. I've never thought of it that way. Mikela: Well well well, congratulations! The world makes sense!
🗓️ Calendar Murder Mystery
Mikela: A man was found dead while on holiday in the UK. The suspects where Margret, Mason, Bill, laura, and Alexa. On the calendar, 3, 4, 9, 10, 11 where written in blood. How do you decloe the numbers to find the killer?
Zoey: If you have time to write so many numbers why not just write their name. XD Tanya: Mason. March, April, September, October, November. Mikela: Congratulations! Casey: Too fast! Zoey: One more please. XD
🚪 Four-story murder
Mikela: A dead body is seen outisde a four-story building. The detective ran up the first floor and checked the window. He checked the windows of floors 2nd, 3rd, 4th, and 5th too. When he came down, he said it wasn't a suicide but a murder. How?
Sasha: Why would a four-story building have a 5th floor? Casey: Is it becausse all the windows are closed? I know someone innocent could have closed the window afterward, but for these puzzles it is worth a shot. Mikela: Congratulations! That's the answer! Zoey: Can we play 221B? XD
Everyone is a winner!

This is Magic Bakery Plays 221B Baker Street Case 6! The game content is probably rated teens to adult. ⚠️ Sasha: We will enter drumroll after revealing 5 clues. If you want to get a WIN credit you must join before the drumroll section.
🚨 Case 7: The Bones of Contention
Sasha: Magic Detectives are called to help find the missing Sumatra bones for an exhibit. We are tasked to find:
a: Who took the Sumatra bones;
b: Where the bones are hidden;
c: The motive.
⭐ Timeline
StarTree: The quest giver is an archeologist, here is his report of what happened so far:
Expetdition: The Archeologist and his assistant found a skeleon called the Sumatra Man during an expedition. The discovery made to the news as the oldest evidence of mankind.
Dock: The archeologist duo arrived at the dock.
Park: When the duo were transporting two packing cases across the park, their lorry was struck and overturned by a carriage driven by a Play Actor. The duo righted the lorry, reloaded the cases and headed to the museum.
Museum: The Duo met the Curator of the museum. The three added to the Pub while the museum's maintenance man was adjusting the heating ducts of the exhibit room.
Pub, Hotel: After the pub, the three met an artifact expert at the hotel to authenticate the Sumatra bones. But when they arrived at the hotel, they learned the the expert had already gone to the museum, so they returned there.
Museum: The duo opened the packing cases with the expert and curator present, but the Sumatra bones were gone. All that remained were some micellaneous artifacts.
Detectives Office: After learning that the bones were gone, the Archeologist asked the Curator for the best detectives in town, which led them to us. Tanya: The Archeologist came to us with a suicase with custom marks of Sumatra. He looks pale, suggesting that he got malaria in the jungles. There is bone dust under his fingernails.
Sasha: There isn't much more information than the above so we will not have a persons or scene section. Tanya: May I see the card? Tanya: I added some more details above. ⚔️ [249] Hotel
Evelyn: Evelyn casts group raise. Evelyn: This is a syllable clue for for the Thief: Part 2 of 2: It can be done with a pen or pencil. In names this matches the Archeologist or the Curator.
Evelyn: May I roll to decide if the Archelogist is undead? Cardinal: Is your preference that he is or is not? Evelyn: I don't know. 😖 Cardinal: Roll two dice please. Evelyn: ➖➖ Cardinal: Evelyn sees that the Archeologist has become undead.
⚔️ [274] Pawnbroker
Tanya: While Evelyn is raising the rest of the team, Tanya had called for backup. But it doesn't seem that reinforcement would arrive before the demon warps to Arx. Tanya: This clue is that the assistant has no scholarly background in archeology.
Sasha: Last clue!
⚔️ [214] Pub
Sylvia: As the undead demon walks close to the pub, Sylvia shoots the holy water that Evelyn had left for her at the floating skull. Sylvia: The clue is a syllable clue for the thief. Part 1 of 2: A part of the foot. This matches the Archeologist and the Actor.
Cardinal: Roll two dice please. Sylvia: ➕➖ Cardinal: Sylvia's shot hit the skull, but it was not enough to stop the demon's escape.
🛎️ SOLUTION
Cardinal: As the detectives regroup, they come to the conclusion that the demon is still to weak to breach the defense of Arx. But that is not a relieve to anyone, as they also know that the day by day, the demon at larger might gain enough power to do so. They will have to fight this demon again. How soon? No one knows.
💗Sasha: Further investigation showed that when the Archeologist was dying by malaria, the demon lured him to uncover an ancient sealed skull. With that, the demon led the Archeologist to Magic Detectives, the last known location of the Eyes of Lucifer. As the demon considered following the trace to warp to there the Eyes of Lucifer were, the demon realized that it was a trap and changed course, escaping for the moment.
Sasha: Well it was a TPK. GG. Sasha: Please return for the revenge!
To be continued...!

202210151642|Bookshelves

 202307230723|📈 Challenger Sale {"cmd":"PIN2","node":"202307230723","music":""}
Challenger Sale
Book
The Challenger Sale:
Taking Control of the Customer Conversation

{"cmd":"url","url":"https://www.amazon.com/The-Challenger-Sale-audiobook/dp/B07SLDD5YV","desc":"[Amazon]"} {"cmd":"url","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Challenger_Sale","desc":"[Wiki]"}
The Challenger Sale is based on research conducted by the Corporate Executive Board (CEB) on sales performance. The book challenges traditional sales approaches and outlines a new method for sales success by challenging their customers' thinking, creating value through insights, and establishing themselves as trusted partners rather than mere transactional vendors.
Lesson 1: The Challenger Sales Approach
The book introduces the concept of the "Challenger Sales Rep," who stands out among other salespeople by taking control of the sales process and guiding the customer through it proactively.
Lesson 2: Teach, Tailor, Take Control
Challengers excel at three critical behaviors. They teach the customer about new insights and ideas, tailor their message to the customer's specific needs, and take control of the conversation by leading the customer towards a solution.
Lesson 3: Rethinking Customer Needs
Rather than just responding to customers' stated needs, Challengers provoke them to consider unexplored challenges and opportunities. They present disruptive insights that compel customers to think differently about their business.
Lesson 4: Building Constructive Tension
Challengers are skilled at creating "constructive tension" during the sales process. They artfully push back on customers' preconceptions, provoking thought and driving the conversation towards value-added solutions.
Lesson 5: Emotional Resonance
Successful sales reps also create an emotional connection with the customer, establishing trust and credibility. They instill confidence in the customer by showcasing their expertise.
Lesson 6: Understanding Stakeholders and Navigating Complex Sales
Challengers are adept at identifying and engaging with different stakeholders involved in the decision-making process. They can navigate complex sales scenarios and tailor their approach to each stakeholder's unique perspective.
Lesson 7: Sales Team Training and Hiring
The book advocates for sales organizations to identify, train, and support Challenger Sales Reps. This involves hiring individuals with the right attributes and providing ongoing coaching and feedback to enhance their performance.
Lesson 8: Adapting to Digital Selling
The Challenger approach is adaptable to digital selling environments. It emphasizes leveraging technology to enhance sales effectiveness while maintaining the core principles of teaching, tailoring, and taking control.
Lesson 9: Sales Management and Leadership
Sales leaders play a crucial role in driving the adoption of the Challenger Sales approach within their organizations. They must support and reinforce the new behaviors and provide the necessary resources for success.
💬 Discussions
{"id":"202307230723","parentid":"202210151642","parentname":"Bookshelves","icon":"📈","title":"Challenger Sale","subtitle":"Book","img":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/I/41Zs-2qu8OL.jpg","music":"","author":"Sasha","description":"","card-text":""}

Black: And also just using the sandbox as a multicolumn browser. StarTree: It seems various sites block itself from being displayed within iframe, so this feature will mainly be for the purpose Tanya said. Ivy: URL beginning with http can't be shown in iframe. StarTree: Adding text input box. Button code. Testing. Adding new panel template. Changing Add Panel code to use template. Done! Tanya: Thank you.
